message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Proceedings of the 30th International Conference on Intelligent User Interfaces
Paper Abstract: user interfaces mediate between person and machine to increase the ease and effectiveness of user interactions. Research in intelligent user interfaces draws on areas such as artificial and human-computer interaction to study methods for supporting varied users for a wide range of tasks, task environments, platforms, and interaction paradigms. The IUI conference is the annual meeting of the intelligent interfaces community, and serves as the principal international forum for reporting outstanding research and development in intelligent user interfaces. IUI'03, the Seventh IUI, was held at The Palms South Beach hotel in Miami Beach, Florida, USA, from January 12-15, 2003. special theme of the conference was highlighting interfaces whose focus goes beyond rational intelligence to address psychological concerns such as emotion, personality, and motivationIUI'03 solicited submissions in three categories, long papers, describing mature work; short papers, describing work in progress, and brief abstracts of system demonstrations. The conference received 134 submissions, an all-time record, including 80 long papers and 49 short papers. Based on rigorous review by an international program committee, 28 papers were selected for oral presentation, with 45 additional submissions featured as posters and demonstrations. Oral presentations spanned the areas of adaptive and collaborative interfaces, affective interfaces, agent-based interfaces, knowledge acquisition and visualization, model-based interface design, multimodal input, and natural language interfacesThe conference program highlighted three invited talks: Daniel Weld presented What Users Want, Hiroshi Ishii presented Tangible Bits: Designing the Seamless Interface between People, Bits, and Atoms, and Allen Gorin presented Semantic Information Processing of Spoken Language in 'How May I Help You?'  (sm). The panel A Life without Friction: Tales from the InfoLab, chaired by Kristian Hammond and Larry Birnbaum, gave an in-depth view of IUI research at the Information Laboratory of Northwestern University, and the panel XML: The Lingua Franca of IUIs?, chaired by Angel Puerta, examined the role of standardization of interoperation and data interchange in the IUI software industry. The conference opened with two tutorials, Intelligent User Interfaces: An Introduction, by Mark Maybury, and Recommender Systems: Interfaces and Technology, by John Riedl and Joseph Konstan
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Adaptive Interfaces"

Links: [{"title":"Adaptive user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_user_interface"},{"title":"Talk:Adaptive user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Adaptive_user_interface"},{"title":"Red Cedar Technology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_Cedar_Technology"},{"title":"Inclusive design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Design_justice"},{"title":"Smart antenna - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smart_antenna"},{"title":"Adapter pattern - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adapter_pattern"}]

Here are the search results for "Adaptive Interfaces":

## Adaptive User Interfaces

An adaptive user interface (AUI) is a user interface which adapts, that is changes, its layout and elements to the needs of the user or context and is similarly alterable by each user.

### Key Characteristics

In a true AUI, elements that comprise the interface's components are innate to the qualities of both adapting and being adaptable, so portions of the interface might adapt to and affect other portions of the interface.

### Advantages

The advantages of an adaptive user interface are found within its ability to conform to a user's needs. The properties of an AUI allow showing only relevant information based on the current user, which creates less confusion for less experienced users and provides ease of access throughout a system.

### Challenges

Key disadvantages include:
- The AUI must be designed with varying levels of implementation in mind and coupled with a way to measure a particular user's needs, and requires knowing a user's goal in order to most efficiently adapt.
- This can give rise to security issues and users lack privacy when utilizing an AUI because information is stored.

### Applications

One common implementation of an AUI is in the medical industry, where the AUI is used to differentiate and specify which information should be shown to which type of user.

Web search results for query: "Multimodal Input"

Links: [{"title":"Multimodal interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_interaction"},{"title":"Multisensory integration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multisensory_integration"},{"title":"Multimodal search - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_search"},{"title":"Multimodal learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_learning"},{"title":"Trajectory inference - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trajectory_inference"},{"title":"Prompt injection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prompt_injection"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of multimodal input:

## Definition and Scope

Multimodal interaction refers to the "interaction with the virtual and physical environment through natural modes of communication". Multimodal systems allow users to interact through input modalities, such as speech, handwriting, hand gesture and gaze.

## How It Works

A multimodal system must recognize inputs from different modalities, combining them according to temporal and contextual constraints to allow their interpretation through a process known as multimodal fusion.

## Key Advantages

The advantage of multiple input modalities is increased usability: the weaknesses of one modality are offset by the strengths of another. Additionally, a well-designed multimodal application can be used by people with a wide variety of impairments, with visually impaired users relying on the voice modality and hearing-impaired users relying on the visual modality.

## Applications

Multimodal learning integrates and processes multiple types of data such as text, audio, images, or video, allowing for a more holistic understanding of complex data and improving model performance in tasks like visual question answering, cross-modal retrieval, and text-to-image generation.

Large multimodal models, such as Google Gemini and GPT-4o, have become increasingly popular since 2023.

Moran - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_P._Moran"}]

## Human-Computer Interaction (HCI)

Human–computer interaction (HCI) is the process through which people operate and engage with computer systems.(no content)Research in HCI covers the design and the use of computer technology, which focuses on the interfaces between people (users) and computers.

### Definition and Scope

The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) defines human–computer interaction as "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them".

### Interdisciplinary Nature

HCI is inherently interdisciplinary. Human–computer interaction studies a human and a machine in communication, drawing from supporting knowledge on both the machine and the human side. On the machine side, techniques in computer graphics, operating systems, programming languages, and development environments are relevant. On the human side, communication theory, graphic and industrial design disciplines, linguistics, social sciences, cognitive psychology, social psychology, and human factors such as computer user satisfaction are relevant.

### Key Interaction Areas

Modern HCI encompasses various interaction modalities, including:
- Gesture recognition, which involves identifying and interpreting gestures made by users
- Gaze detection (eye-movement tracking), which involves tracking the movement of a user's eyes and is primarily used to better understand the user's attention, intent, or focus
- Facial expression analysis, which focuses on visually recognizing and analyzing emotions through facial expressions

### Historical Significance

The first known use of the term "human-computer interaction" was in 1975 by Carlisle. The field gained further prominence with influential academic work in the 1980s.

## Human-Computer Interaction (HCI)

Human–computer interaction (HCI) is the process through which people operate and engage with computer systems.(no content)Research in HCI covers the design and the use of computer technology, which focuses on the interfaces between people (users) and computers.

### Definition and Scope

The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) defines human–computer interaction as "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them".

### Interdisciplinary Nature

HCI is inherently interdisciplinary. Human–computer interaction studies a human and a machine in communication, drawing from supporting knowledge on both the machine and the human side. On the machine side, techniques in computer graphics, operating systems, programming languages, and development environments are relevant. On the human side, communication theory, graphic and industrial design disciplines, linguistics, social sciences, cognitive psychology, social psychology, and human factors such as computer user satisfaction are relevant.

### Key Interaction Areas

Modern HCI encompasses various interaction modalities, including:
- Gesture recognition, which involves identifying and interpreting gestures made by users
- Gaze detection (eye-movement tracking), which involves tracking the movement of a user's eyes and is primarily used to better understand the user's attention, intent, or focus
- Facial expression analysis, which focuses on visually recognizing and analyzing emotions through facial expressions

### Historical Significance

The first known use of the term "human-computer interaction" was in 1975 by Carlisle. The field gained further prominence with influential academic work in the 1980s.

Web search results for query: "Agent-Based Model"

Links: [{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"Agent-based model in biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model_in_biology"},{"title":"Agent-based social simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_social_simulation"},{"title":"Comparison of agent-based modeling software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_agent-based_modeling_software"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Agent-based computational economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_computational_economics"},{"title":"Agent-based modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Agent-based_modeling&redirect=no"},{"title":"GAMA Platform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GAMA_Platform"},{"title":"Sugarscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sugarscape"},{"title":"AI agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Agent-Based Models:

## Definition

An agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as organizations or groups) in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.

## Key Characteristics

Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena.(no content)The process is one of emergence, where "the whole is greater than the sum of its parts" - higher-level system properties emerge from the interactions of lower-level subsystems.(no content)Individual agents are typically characterized as boundedly rational, presumed to be acting in what they perceive as their own interests, such as reproduction, economic benefit, or social status, using heuristics or simple decision-making rules.

## Components

Most agent-based models are composed of: (1) numerous agents specified at various scales; (2) decision-making heuristics; (3) learning rules or adaptive processes; (4) an interaction topology; and (5) an environment.

## Implementation

ABMs are typically implemented as computer simulations, either as custom software, or via ABM toolkits, and this software can be then used to test how changes in individual behaviors will affect the system's emerging overall behavior.

## Historical Development

The idea of agent-based modeling was developed as a relatively simple concept in the late 1940s. Since it requires computation-intensive procedures, it did not become widespread until the 1990s.

## Applications

Agent-based models are used across multiple domains including biology, economics, social sciences, and environmental management to understand and predict complex system behaviors.

Links: [{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Applications of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Timeline of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_video_games"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence visual art - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_art"},{"title":"Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence:_A_Modern_Approach"},{"title":"List of artificial intelligence films - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_artificial_intelligence_films"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence arms race - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_arms_race"},{"title":"Ethics of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence"}]

## Artificial Intelligence - Search Results

I found comprehensive information about Artificial Intelligence. Here's a summary of the key findings:

### Definition and Goals

Artificial intelligence is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.(no content)The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.

### History

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

### Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)

Artificial general intelligence (AGI)—sometimes called human‑level intelligence AI—is a type of artificial intelligence that would match or surpass human capabilities across virtually all cognitive tasks.(no content)Unlike artificial narrow intelligence (ANI), whose competence is confined to well‑defined tasks, an AGI system can generalise knowledge, transfer skills between domains, and solve novel problems without task‑specific reprogramming.

### Current Applications

Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data. The search results show AI is being used across various sectors including medicine, astronomy, military operations, art, music composition, and video game development.

### Ethical Considerations

The ethics of artificial intelligence covers a broad range of topics including algorithmic biases, fairness, accountability, transparency, privacy, and regulation, particularly where systems influence or automate human decision-making.

Web search results for query: "Model-Based Design"

Links: [{"title":"Model-based design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-based_design"},{"title":"Model-based definition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-based_definition"},{"title":"Model-based systems engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-based_systems_engineering"},{"title":"Model-based testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-based_testing"},{"title":"Model-driven architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-driven_architecture"},{"title":"Model-centered instruction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-centered_instruction"},{"title":"Business model canvas - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business_model_canvas"},{"title":"UML-based Web Engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UML-based_Web_Engineering"},{"title":"Waco Mailplanes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waco_Mailplanes"},{"title":"KGM Musso EV - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KGM_Musso_EV"}]

Here are the search results for "Model-Based Design":

## Overview

Model-based design (MBD) is a mathematical and visual method of addressing problems associated with designing complex control, signal processing and communication systems.(no content)It is used in many motion control, industrial equipment, aerospace, and automotive applications.

## Key Steps

The main steps in the model-based design approach include:

1. **Plant Modeling**: Plant modeling can be data-driven or based on first principles.(no content)Data-driven plant modeling uses techniques such as System identification, where the plant model is identified by acquiring and processing raw data from a real-world system and choosing a mathematical algorithm with which to identify a mathematical model.

2. **Controller Analysis and Synthesis**: The mathematical model conceived in the first step is used to identify dynamic characteristics of the plant model, and a controller can then be synthesized based on these characteristics.

3. **Simulation**: The time response of the dynamic system to complex, time-varying inputs is investigated by simulating a simple LTI (Linear Time-Invariant) model, or by simulating a non-linear model of the plant with the controller.(no content)Simulation allows specification, requirements, and modeling errors to be found immediately, rather than later in the design effort.

4. **Deployment**: Ideally this is done via code generation from the controller developed in step 2.

## Key Benefits

Model-based design tools allow all these iterative steps to be performed in a unified visual environment.

The search results also revealed related concepts like Model-Based Systems Engineering (MBSE), Model-Based Testing, and Model-Based Definition, which are specialized applications of model-based methodologies in different domains.

Here are the search results for "Model-Based Design":

## Overview

Model-based design (MBD) is a mathematical and visual method of addressing problems associated with designing complex control, signal processing and communication systems.(no content)It is used in many motion control, industrial equipment, aerospace, and automotive applications.

## Key Steps

The main steps in the model-based design approach include:

1. **Plant Modeling**: Plant modeling can be data-driven or based on first principles.(no content)Data-driven plant modeling uses techniques such as System identification, where the plant model is identified by acquiring and processing raw data from a real-world system and choosing a mathematical algorithm with which to identify a mathematical model.

2. **Controller Analysis and Synthesis**: The mathematical model conceived in the first step is used to identify dynamic characteristics of the plant model, and a controller can then be synthesized based on these characteristics.

3. **Simulation**: The time response of the dynamic system to complex, time-varying inputs is investigated by simulating a simple LTI (Linear Time-Invariant) model, or by simulating a non-linear model of the plant with the controller.(no content)Simulation allows specification, requirements, and modeling errors to be found immediately, rather than later in the design effort.

4. **Deployment**: Ideally this is done via code generation from the controller developed in step 2.

## Key Benefits

Model-based design tools allow all these iterative steps to be performed in a unified visual environment.

The search results also revealed related concepts like Model-Based Systems Engineering (MBSE), Model-Based Testing, and Model-Based Definition, which are specialized applications of model-based methodologies in different domains.

Links: [{"title":"Data and information visualization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_and_information_visualization"},{"title":"Information Visualization (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_Visualization_(journal)"},{"title":"Chord diagram (information visualization) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chord_diagram_(information_visualization)"},{"title":"Starlight Information Visualization System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starlight_Information_Visualization_System"},{"title":"Visualization (graphics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visualization_(graphics)"},{"title":"Information visualization reference model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_visualization_reference_model"},{"title":"Category:Data and information visualization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Data_and_information_visualization"},{"title":"List of information graphics software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_information_graphics_software"},{"title":"Edward Tufte - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Tufte"},{"title":"Visual analytics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_analytics"}]

## Information Visualization

Information visualization is the practice of designing and creating graphic or visual representations of quantitative and qualitative data and information with the help of static, dynamic or interactive visual items.

### Purpose and Goals

These visualizations are intended to help a target audience visually explore and discover, quickly understand, interpret and gain important insights into otherwise difficult-to-identify structures, relationships, correlations, local and global patterns, trends, variations, constancy, clusters, outliers and unusual groupings within data.

### Key Characteristics

Information visualization concentrates on the use of computer-supported tools to explore large amounts of abstract data.(no content)Information visualization deals with multiple, large-scale and complicated datasets which contain quantitative data, as well as qualitative, and primarily abstract information, and its goal is to add value to raw data, improve the viewers' comprehension, reinforce their cognition and help derive insights and make decisions as they navigate and interact with the graphical display.

### Visual Formats and Tools

Visual tools used include maps for location based data; hierarchical organisations of data; displays that prioritise relationships such as Sankey diagrams; flowcharts, timelines.

### Importance and Applications

Data and information visualization is interdisciplinary, it incorporates principles found in descriptive statistics, visual communication, graphic design, cognitive science and interactive computer graphics and human-computer interaction. Since effective visualization requires design skills, statistical skills and computing skills, it is both an art and a science.

Web search results for query: "Affective Computing"

Links: [{"title":"Affective computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_computing"},{"title":"Category:Affective computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Affective_computing"},{"title":"Rosalind Picard - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosalind_Picard"},{"title":"Affective design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_design"},{"title":"Talk:Affective computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Affective_computing"},{"title":"Affective haptics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_haptics"},{"title":"Emotions in virtual communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotions_in_virtual_communication"},{"title":"Kismet (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kismet_(robot)"},{"title":"Affect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect"},{"title":"Artificial empathy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_empathy"}]

Here are the search results for **Affective Computing**:

## Definition and Overview

Affective computing is the study and development of systems and devices that can recognize, interpret, process, and simulate human affects. It is an interdisciplinary field spanning computer science, psychology, and cognitive science.

## Historical Origins

The modern branch of computer science originated with Rosalind Picard's 1995 paper entitled "Affective Computing" and her 1997 book of the same name published by MIT Press.(no content)One of the motivations for the research is the ability to give machines emotional intelligence, including to simulate empathy.

## Key Goals

The machine should interpret the emotional state of humans and adapt its behavior to them, giving an appropriate response to those emotions.

## Technologies and Methods

Machine learning techniques process different modalities, such as speech recognition, natural language processing, or facial expression detection.(no content)Various changes in the autonomic nervous system can indirectly alter a person's speech, and affective technologies can leverage this information to recognize emotion. For example, speech produced in a state of fear, anger, or joy becomes fast, loud, and precisely enunciated, with a higher and wider range in pitch, whereas emotions such as tiredness, boredom, or sadness tend to generate slow, low-pitched, and slurred speech.

## Applications

The Affective Computing Research Group develops tools, techniques, and devices for sensing, interpreting, and processing emotion signals that drive state-of-the-art systems that respond intelligently to human emotional states. Applications of their research include improved tutoring systems and assistive technology for use in addressing the verbal communications difficulties experienced by individuals with autism.

Links: [{"title":"Knowledge Acquisition and Documentation Structuring - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_Acquisition_and_Documentation_Structuring"},{"title":"Knowledge acquisition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_acquisition"},{"title":"Implicit and explicit knowledge - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Implicit_and_explicit_knowledge"},{"title":"Knowledge of human nature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_of_human_nature"},{"title":"Innateness hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innateness_hypothesis"},{"title":"Transversal Corporation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transversal_Corporation"},{"title":"Experiential knowledge - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experiential_knowledge"},{"title":"Knowledge - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge"},{"title":"Nexient Learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nexient_Learning"},{"title":"Skill - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skill"}]

## Knowledge Acquisition

Based on the search results, here's an overview of knowledge acquisition:

### Definition and Purpose

Knowledge acquisition is the process used to define the rules and ontologies required for a knowledge-based system.(no content)The phrase was first used in conjunction with expert systems to describe the initial tasks associated with developing an expert system, namely finding and interviewing domain experts and capturing their knowledge via rules, objects, and frame-based ontologies.

### Historical Context

Expert systems were one of the first successful applications of artificial intelligence technology to real world business problems, with researchers at Stanford and other AI laboratories working with doctors and other highly skilled experts to develop systems that could automate complex tasks such as medical diagnosis.

### Scope and Applications

Knowledge acquisition has been applied to many fields beyond expert systems, including natural language processing, decision support systems, training simulations, and intelligent tutoring systems, and it also plays an essential role in building knowledge-based agents and cognitive architectures.

### Techniques

A variety of techniques exist for knowledge acquisition, ranging from manual to automatic methods, with manual approaches including structured interviews, protocol analysis, card sorting, and repertory grid analysis.

### Modern Approaches

A more recent approach to knowledge acquisition is a re-use based approach where knowledge can be developed in ontologies that conform to standards such as the Web Ontology Language (OWL), in which way knowledge can be standardized and shared across a broad community of knowledge workers.

Knowledge acquisition is the process used to define the rules and ontologies required for a knowledge-based system.(no content)The phrase was first used in conjunction with expert systems to describe the initial tasks associated with developing an expert system, namely finding and interviewing domain experts and capturing their knowledge via rules, objects, and frame-based ontologies.

### Historical Context

Expert systems were one of the first successful applications of artificial intelligence technology to real world business problems, with researchers at Stanford and other AI laboratories working with doctors and other highly skilled experts to develop systems that could automate complex tasks such as medical diagnosis.

### Scope and Applications

Knowledge acquisition has been applied to many fields beyond expert systems, including natural language processing, decision support systems, training simulations, and intelligent tutoring systems, and it also plays an essential role in building knowledge-based agents and cognitive architectures.

### Techniques

A variety of techniques exist for knowledge acquisition, ranging from manual to automatic methods, with manual approaches including structured interviews, protocol analysis, card sorting, and repertory grid analysis.

### Modern Approaches

A more recent approach to knowledge acquisition is a re-use based approach where knowledge can be developed in ontologies that conform to standards such as the Web Ontology Language (OWL), in which way knowledge can be standardized and shared across a broad community of knowledge workers.

Web search results for query: "Collaborative Interfaces"

Links: [{"title":"Business interoperability interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business_interoperability_interface"},{"title":"Computer-supported cooperative work - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer-supported_collaboration"},{"title":"Collaborative real-time editor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_real-time_editor"},{"title":"List of collaborative software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_collaborative_software"},{"title":"Collaborative software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_software"},{"title":"Collabora Online - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Draft:Collabora_Online"},{"title":"Human-centered computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human-centered_computing"},{"title":"Outline of human–computer interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_human-computer_interaction_topics"},{"title":"Integrated collaboration environment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrated_collaboration_environment"},{"title":"Human–computer interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–computer_interaction"}]

Here's what I found on Collaborative Interfaces:

## Overview

Computer-supported collaborative work (CSCW) or computer-supported collaboration is the study of how people utilize technology collaboratively, often towards a shared goal.(no content)CSCW addresses how computer systems can support collaborative activity and coordination.

## Key Types

Collaborative software may be divided into real-time collaborative editing platforms that allow multiple users to engage in live, simultaneous, and reversible editing of a single file; and version control platforms, which allow users to make parallel edits to a file, while preserving every saved edit by users as multiple files that are variants of the original file.

## Business and Organizational Context

In a business context, a business interoperability interface (BII) is an interface that enables business interoperability between organizational systems.(no content)The BII should enable the enactment of collaborative business processes and interconnect the business processes of different organizations, with the main objective of describing to collaboration partners how they can interact with an organization.

## Integrated Collaboration Environments

An integrated collaboration environment (ICE) is an environment in which a virtual team does its work, and such environments allow companies to realize a number of competitive advantages by using their existing computers and network infrastructure for group and personal collaboration.

## Historical Context

Douglas Engelbart first envisioned collaborative computing in 1951 and documented his vision in 1962, with the first public demonstration of his work in 1968 in what is now referred to as "The Mother of All Demos".

Links: [{"title":"Natural language processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing"},{"title":"History of natural language processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_natural_language_processing"},{"title":"Outline of natural language processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_natural_language_processing"},{"title":"Semantic decomposition (natural language processing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_decomposition_(natural_language_processing)"},{"title":"Category:Tasks of natural language processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Tasks_of_natural_language_processing"},{"title":"Studies in Natural Language Processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Studies_in_Natural_Language_Processing"},{"title":"Category:Natural language processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Natural_language_processing"},{"title":"Category:Natural language processing software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Natural_language_processing_software"},{"title":"Natural Language Processing (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_Language_Processing_(journal)"},{"title":"Quantum natural language processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_natural_language_processing"}]

Here are the search results for Natural Language Processing:

## Overview

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer and is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)NLP is also related to information retrieval, knowledge representation, computational linguistics, and linguistics more broadly.

## Key Tasks

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include: speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

## Historical Development

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s when Alan Turing published an article proposing the Turing test as a criterion of intelligence, which included a task involving the automated interpretation and generation of natural language.(no content)Until the 1980s, most natural language processing systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution in natural language processing with the introduction of machine learning algorithms.

## Modern Developments

The Transformer architecture was introduced in 2017, laying the foundation for advances in NLP.(no content)The concept of large language model (LLM) emerged in late 2010s as a language model trained with self-supervised learning on vast amounts of text.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

Links: [{"title":"Personality psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_psychology"},{"title":"Journal of Personality and Social Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Personality_and_Social_Psychology"},{"title":"Society for Personality and Social Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_for_Personality_and_Social_Psychology"},{"title":"Personality and Social Psychology Review - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_and_Social_Psychology_Review"},{"title":"Personality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality"},{"title":"Personality test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_test"},{"title":"Personality type - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_type"},{"title":"Individual psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Individual_psychology"},{"title":"Personality development - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_development"},{"title":"Big Five personality traits - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Five_personality_traits"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Personality Psychology:

## Definition and Scope

Personality psychology is a branch of psychology that examines personality and its variation among individuals, aiming to show how people are individually different due to psychological forces.(no content)Personality is a dynamic and organized set of characteristics possessed by an individual that uniquely influences their environment, cognition, emotions, motivations, and behaviors in various situations.

## Key Areas of Study

Research in personality psychology generally attempts to explain the characteristics of a person that underlie differences in behavior, with personality characteristics being related to many life outcomes, such as work and relationship success, mental health, well-being and longevity.

## Major Theoretical Approaches

The major theories include dispositional (trait) perspective, psychodynamic, humanistic, biological, behaviorist, evolutionary, and social learning perspective.(no content)Over time, psychologists have taken many different approaches to study personality, which can be organized across dispositional, biological, intrapsychic (psychodynamic), cognitive-experiential, social and cultural, and adjustment domains.

## The Big Five Model

The most widely accepted empirical model of durable, universal personality descriptors is the system of Big Five personality traits: conscientiousness, agreeableness, neuroticism, openness to experience, and extraversion-introversion.

## Personality Types vs. Traits

According to type theories, there are two types of people, introverts and extroverts, whereas according to trait theories, introversion and extroversion are part of a continuous dimension with many people in the middle.

Links: [{"title":"Personality psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_psychology"},{"title":"Journal of Personality and Social Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Personality_and_Social_Psychology"},{"title":"Society for Personality and Social Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_for_Personality_and_Social_Psychology"},{"title":"Personality and Social Psychology Review - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_and_Social_Psychology_Review"},{"title":"Personality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality"},{"title":"Personality test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_test"},{"title":"Personality type - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_type"},{"title":"Individual psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Individual_psychology"},{"title":"Personality development - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_development"},{"title":"Big Five personality traits - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Five_personality_traits"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Personality Psychology:

## Definition and Scope

Personality psychology is a branch of psychology that examines personality and its variation among individuals, aiming to show how people are individually different due to psychological forces.(no content)Personality is a dynamic and organized set of characteristics possessed by an individual that uniquely influences their environment, cognition, emotions, motivations, and behaviors in various situations.

## Key Areas of Study

Research in personality psychology generally attempts to explain the characteristics of a person that underlie differences in behavior, with personality characteristics being related to many life outcomes, such as work and relationship success, mental health, well-being and longevity.

## Major Theoretical Approaches

The major theories include dispositional (trait) perspective, psychodynamic, humanistic, biological, behaviorist, evolutionary, and social learning perspective.(no content)Over time, psychologists have taken many different approaches to study personality, which can be organized across dispositional, biological, intrapsychic (psychodynamic), cognitive-experiential, social and cultural, and adjustment domains.

## The Big Five Model

The most widely accepted empirical model of durable, universal personality descriptors is the system of Big Five personality traits: conscientiousness, agreeableness, neuroticism, openness to experience, and extraversion-introversion.

## Personality Types vs. Traits

According to type theories, there are two types of people, introverts and extroverts, whereas according to trait theories, introversion and extroversion are part of a continuous dimension with many people in the middle.

Web search results for query: "Emotion Recognition"

Links: [{"title":"Emotion recognition in conversation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotion_recognition_in_conversation"},{"title":"Emotion recognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotion_recognition"},{"title":"List of facial expression databases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facial_expression_databases"},{"title":"Affective computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_computing"},{"title":"Object recognition (cognitive science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_object_recognition_(animal_test)"},{"title":"OpenSMILE - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenSMILE"},{"title":"Facial expression - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facial_expression"},{"title":"Reverence (emotion) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverence_(emotion)"},{"title":"Face - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_faces"},{"title":"Affectiva - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affectiva"}]

Here are the search results for "Emotion Recognition":

## Overview

Emotion recognition is the process of identifying human emotion.(no content)Use of technology to help people with emotion recognition is a relatively nascent research area.

## Technology and Approaches

The technology works best if it uses multiple modalities in context. To date, the most work has been conducted on automating the recognition of facial expressions from video, spoken expressions from audio, written expressions from text, and physiology as measured by wearables.(no content)The accuracy of emotion recognition is usually improved when it combines the analysis of human expressions from multimodal forms such as texts, physiology, audio, or video.

## Methods and Techniques

There is an extensive literature proposing and evaluating hundreds of different kinds of methods, leveraging techniques from multiple areas, such as signal processing, machine learning, computer vision, and speech processing.(no content)Deep learning is widely employed in emotion recognition. Well-known deep learning algorithms include different architectures of Artificial Neural Network such as Convolutional Neural Network, Long Short-term Memory, and Extreme Learning Machine.

## Related Field: Emotion Recognition in Conversation

Emotion recognition in conversation is a sub-field of emotion recognition that focuses on mining human emotions from conversations or dialogues having two or more interlocutors.

## Practical Applications

Emotion recognition software can detect complex and nuanced emotions and cognitive states by analyzing the human face, vocal intonations and body posture.

Web search results for query: "Motivation Psychology"

Links: [{"title":"Motivation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motivation"},{"title":"Motivation crowding theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motivation_crowding_theory"},{"title":"Industrial and organizational psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_and_organizational_psychology"},{"title":"Work motivation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Work_motivation"},{"title":"Self-determination theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-determination_theory"},{"title":"Psychology of learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychology_of_learning"},{"title":"Dalbir Bindra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dalbir_Bindra"},{"title":"Magdalen Dorothea Vernon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magdalen_Dorothea_Vernon"},{"title":"Drive theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drive_theory"},{"title":"Category:Motivation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Motivation"}]

I've performed a web search for "Motivation Psychology" and found comprehensive information on the topic. Here are the key findings:

## Definition

Motivation is an internal state that propels individuals to engage in goal-directed behavior.(no content)It is often understood as a force that explains why people or other animals initiate, continue, or terminate a certain behavior at a particular time.

## Study of Motivation

The traditional discipline studying motivation is psychology, which investigates how motivation arises, which factors influence it, and what effects it has.(no content)Motivation science is a more recent field of inquiry focused on an integrative approach that tries to link insights from different subdisciplines.

## Key Psychological Processes

Motivation involves three psychological processes: arousal, direction, and intensity.(no content)Arousal is what initiates action and is often fueled by a person's need or desire for something that is missing from their life, either totally or partially.

## Major Theories

The search results reveal several important motivational theories:

- Intrinsic motivation refers to initiating an activity because it is interesting and satisfying to do so, as opposed to doing an activity to obtain an external goal (extrinsic motivation).

- Need-based theories of motivation focus on an employee's drive to satisfy a variety of needs through their work, ranging from basic physiological needs for survival to higher psychoemotional needs like belonging and self-actualization.

- Drive theory is based on the principle that organisms are born with certain psychological needs and that a negative state of tension is created when these needs are not satisfied. When a need is satisfied, drive is reduced and the organism returns to a state of homeostasis and relaxation.

Here are the search results for "Speech Recognition":

## Overview

Speech recognition (automatic speech recognition (ASR), computer speech recognition, or speech-to-text (STT)) is a sub-field of computational linguistics concerned with methods and technologies that translate spoken language into text or other interpretable forms.

## Historical Development

Applications for speech recognition developed over many decades, with progress accelerated due to advances in deep learning and the use of big data. Key milestones include:

- 1952 – Bell Labs researchers built Audrey for single-speaker digit recognition.
- 1962 – IBM's 16-word "Shoebox" machine's speech recognition debuted at the 1962 World's Fair.
- By the mid-1980s, Fred Jelinek's team at IBM created a voice-activated typewriter called Tangora, which could handle a 20,000-word vocabulary.

Web search results for query: "Tangible User Interface"

Links: [{"title":"Tangible user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tangible_user_interface"},{"title":"User interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_interface"},{"title":"Hiroshi Ishii (computer scientist) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hiroshi_Ishii_(computer_scientist)"},{"title":"Tangibility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tangible"},{"title":"Audiocubes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audiocubes"},{"title":"Organic user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organic_user_interface"},{"title":"Natural user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_user_interface"},{"title":"Touch user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Touch_user_interface"},{"title":"Category:User interfaces - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:User_interfaces"},{"title":"Category:User interface techniques - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:User_interface_techniques"}]

## Tangible User Interface (TUI)

A tangible user interface (TUI) is a user interface in which a person interacts with digital information through the physical environment.

### Definition and Purpose

The purpose of TUI development is to empower collaboration, learning, and design by giving physical forms to digital information, thus taking advantage of the human ability to grasp and manipulate physical objects and materials.(no content)The initial name was Graspable User Interface, which is no longer used.

### Key Characteristics

Physical representations are computationally coupled to underlying digital information, embody mechanisms for interactive control, and are perceptually coupled to actively mediated digital representations. Physical state of tangibles embodies key aspects of the digital state of a system.

### TUI vs. GUI

A tangible user interface must be differentiated from a graphical user interface (GUI). A GUI exists only in the digital world, whereas a TUI connects the digital with the physical world.(no content)A tangible user interface represents the input directly in the physical world, and makes the digital information directly graspable.

### Key Pioneers

Hiroshi Ishii, a professor at the MIT who heads the Tangible Media Group at the MIT Media Lab, has a particular vision for tangible UIs, called Tangible Bits, which is to give physical form to digital information, making bits directly manipulable and perceptible.

### Examples

A simple example of tangible UI is the computer mouse: Dragging the mouse over a flat surface moves a pointer on the screen accordingly.(no content)Other examples include the Marble Answering Machine by Durrell Bishop (1992). A marble represents a single message left on the answering machine. Dropping a marble into a dish plays back the associated message or calls back the caller.

I found the Wikipedia article on Human-Computer Interaction. Here's the key information:

## Overview

Human–computer interaction (HCI) is the process through which people operate and engage with computer systems.(no content)Research in HCI covers the design and the use of computer technology, which focuses on the interfaces between people (users) and computers.

## Definition and Scope

The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) defines human–computer interaction as "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them".(no content)Because human–computer interaction studies a human and a machine in communication, it draws from supporting knowledge on both the machine and the human side. On the machine side, techniques in computer graphics, operating systems, programming languages, and development environments are relevant. On the human side, communication theory, graphic and industrial design disciplines, linguistics, social sciences, cognitive psychology, social psychology, and human factors such as computer user satisfaction are relevant.

## Alternative Terminology

HCI is also sometimes termed human–machine interaction (HMI), man-machine interaction (MMI) or computer-human interaction (CHI).

## Key Aspects

A key aspect of HCI is user satisfaction, also referred to as End-User Computing Satisfaction. The field emphasizes that good interface design is critical—poorly designed interfaces can have serious real-world consequences in safety-critical systems.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Excellent! I have successfully completed the analysis of the IUI conference proceedings paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey (not a contribution)

This paper is an editorial/overview of the IUI 2003 conference proceedings, describing the conference theme, presentations, and research areas rather than proposing new methods.

**Extracted Entities:** 16 key technologies and concepts

The analysis identified and validated 16 distinct entities across three categories:
- **Concepts** (12): Human-computer interaction, Artificial intelligence, Adaptive user interfaces, Collaborative interfaces, Affective computing, Agent-based modeling, Data visualization, Multimodal interaction, Tangible user interfaces, Emotion recognition, Personality, and Motivation
- **Methods** (3): Model-based design, Natural language processing, and Speech recognition
- **Tasks** (1): Knowledge acquisition

All entities were extracted from the abstract, mapped to their Wikipedia articles, and cross-referenced with relevance statements explaining their significance to the conference.

**Validation:** Passed ✅

The triples_output.json file has been validated and contains properly formatted entries with correct Wikipedia URLs, relation types, and entity classifications.
